issue.title: Keycloak's own log rotation seems impossible to disable

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: Categorizes a PR related to an enhancement

repository.name: keycloak
repository.description: Open Source Identity and Access Management For Modern Applications and Services

issue.body:
### Before reporting an issue

- [x] I have read and understood the above terms for submitting issues, and I understand that my issue may be closed without action if I do not follow them.

### Area

_No response_

### Describe the bug

We are running KeyCloak on-prem. Logrotation is done system-wide by Linux' logrotate facility. KeyCloak seems to insist on doing its own log rotating which collides with the system-wide mechanism.

This is bad, because:
- Ops need to have *one* interface to configure log rotation. Having to check various service-specific configuration files is not really an option.
- When trying to debug problems with KeyCloak one often wants to use `tail -f keycloak.log`, but this does not work with KeyCloak, because the way it rotates (rename keycloak.log and continue logging into a different file) breaks this. 
- Also there are additional triggers for log rotating which all seem on by default. This is against best practices. Expected log rotate behaviour is once a day. Doing things entirely differently causes a *lot* of work for ops responsible not only for KeyCloak but lots of other services in a data center.

### Version

26.0.0.5

### Regression

- [ ] The issue is a regression

### Expected behavior

KeyCloak should not attempt to rotate logs unless explicitly configured to do so. If this is not possible (because now already people may rely on the previous default) there should bei *one* simple option to entirely disable it.

### Actual behavior

KeyCloak rotates logs by default caused by various triggers (file size, startup, maybe even others). Disabling it seems impossible or at least pretty complicated. I have not yet succeeded in doing so. 

### How to Reproduce?

Install KeyCloak on some Linux server, restart it, use it for some minutes. You will already have at least a keycloak.log and several keycloak.log.[0-9] files.
Try to run `tail -f keycloak.log` while doing so. See that after the first few lines you don't even get an update anymore.

### Anything else?

I understand that most people are probably not too concerned about this because running KeyCloak in containerised environments. However on-prem does exist. And KeyCloak, like every other infrastructure service, should really try to default to best practices.

body: @mbert would you be interested in contributing that?

> [@mbert](https://github.com/mbert) would you be interested in contributing that?

I totally get your point. Unfortunately I am not at all familiar with quarkus, and I will need to survive the current project release stress (where this thing popped up). Please don't get me wrong, it's not laziness, but I don't really see how I can manage now.

> > [@mbert](https://github.com/mbert) would you be interested in contributing that?

> I totally get your point. Unfortunately I am not at all familiar with quarkus, and I will need to survive the current project release stress (where this thing popped up). Please don't get me wrong, it's not laziness, but I don't really see how I can manage now.

No worries, totally understandable!
I think https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/pull/47248 should address the issue.
